fields.name: Genetic Fallacy
fields.description: Dismissing an argument because of who made it
fields.example: Of course you're saying that, you're my friend.
fields.improvement: Thank you, I still didn't do as well as I wanted to.

fields.name: Cherry Picking
fields.description: selecting extreme examples to make a point
fields.example_context: Why should I drive instead of flying?
fields.example: Flying is so dangerous! That Malaysian Airlines flight crashed and hundreds of passengers died.
fields.improvement: Driving is more than 70 times more likely than flying to lead to fatal accidents per mile travelled, so you should fly if safety is your priority.

fields.name: Appeal to Popularity
fields.description: Using the popularity of a premise or proposition as evidence for its truthfulness
fields.example_context: Is the national debt out of control?
fields.improvement: First, what does it mean for debt to be out of control? I think we'd both agree that debt is out of control if interest payments are larger than the debtor's income...

fields.name: Appeal to Ridicule
fields.description: Presenting an argument as ridiculous, implying that it isn't even worth considering
fields.example_context: Why is nudity illegal anyway? What's profane about the human body?
fields.improvement: Maybe public health issues would arrise because of failure to wipe.

fields.name: False Dilemma
fields.description: Acting like there are only two choices when there may be many
fields.example_context: I'm not sure which major I should choose.
fields.example: You're either going to be a doctor or a lawyer, so you have to pick pre-law or pre-med.
fields.improvement: What interests you? You want something that gives you some economic benefit after graduating, but not at the expense of your happiness.
